DATE.d: Returns the number that represents the date in the date-time code
DATE.ad: is a number from 1900 or 1904 (depending on the workbook's date system) to 9999!is a number from 1 to 12 representing the month of the year!is a number from 1 to 31 representing the day of the month

DATEDIF.d: Returns the difference between two date values (start date and end date), based on the interval (unit) specified
DATEDIF.ad: is a date that represents the first, or starting date of a given period!is a date that represents the last, or ending, date of the period!is the type of information that you want returned

DATEVALUE.d: Converts a date in the form of text to a number that represents the date in the date-time code
DATEVALUE.ad: is text that represents a date in a Spreadsheet Editor date format, between 1/1/1900 or 1/1/1904 (depending on the workbook's date system) and 12/31/9999

DAY.d: Returns the day of the month, a number from 1 to 31.
DAY.ad: is a number in the date-time code used by Spreadsheet Editor

DAYS.d: Returns the number of days between the two dates.
DAYS.ad: start_date and end_date are the two dates between which you want to know the number of days!start_date and end_date are the two dates between which you want to know the number of days

DAYS360.d: Returns the number of days between two dates based on a 360-day year (twelve 30-day months)
DAYS360.ad: start_date and end_date are the two dates between which you want to know the number of days!start_date and end_date are the two dates between which you want to know the number of days!is a logical value specifying the calculation method: U.S. (NASD) = FALSE or omitted; European = TRUE.

EDATE.d: Returns the serial number of the date that is the indicated number of months before or after the start date
EDATE.ad: is a serial date number that represents the start date!is the number of months before or after start_date

EOMONTH.d: Returns the serial number of the last day of the month before or after a specified number of months
EOMONTH.ad: is a serial date number that represents the start date!is the number of months before or after the start_date

HOUR.d: Returns the hour as a number from 0 (12:00 A.M.) to 23 (11:00 P.M.).
HOUR.ad: is a number in the date-time code used by Spreadsheet Editor, or text in time format, such as 16:48:00 or 4:48:00 PM

ISOWEEKNUM.d: Returns the ISO week number in the year for a given date
ISOWEEKNUM.ad: is the date-time code used by Spreadsheet Editor for date and time calculation

MINUTE.d: Returns the minute, a number from 0 to 59.
MINUTE.ad: is a number in the date-time code used by Spreadsheet Editor or text in time format, such as 16:48:00 or 4:48:00 PM

MONTH.d: Returns the month, a number from 1 (January) to 12 (December).
MONTH.ad: is a number in the date-time code used by Spreadsheet Editor

NETWORKDAYS.d: Returns the number of whole workdays between two dates
NETWORKDAYS.ad: is a serial date number that represents the start date!is a serial date number that represents the end date!is an optional set of one or more serial date numbers to exclude from the working calendar, such as state and federal holidays and floating holidays

NETWORKDAYS.INTL.d: Returns the number of whole workdays between two dates with custom weekend parameters
NETWORKDAYS.INTL.ad: is a serial date number that represents the start date!is a serial date number that represents the end date!is a number or string specifying when weekends occur!is an optional set of one or more serial date numbers to exclude from the working calendar, such as state and federal holidays and floating holidays

NOW.d: Returns the current date and time formatted as a date and time.

SECOND.d: Returns the second, a number from 0 to 59.
SECOND.ad: is a number in the date-time code used by Spreadsheet Editor or text in time format, such as 16:48:23 or 4:48:47 PM

TIME.d: Converts hours, minutes and seconds given as numbers to a serial number, formatted with a time format
TIME.ad: is a number from 0 to 23 representing the hour!is a number from 0 to 59 representing the minute!is a number from 0 to 59 representing the second

TIMEVALUE.d: Converts a text time to a serial number for a time, a number from 0 (12:00:00 AM) to 0.999988426 (11:59:59 PM). Format the number with a time format after entering the formula
TIMEVALUE.ad: is a text string that gives a time in any one of the Spreadsheet Editor time formats (date information in the string is ignored)

TODAY.d: Returns the current date formatted as a date.

WEEKDAY.d: Returns a number from 1 to 7 identifying the day of the week of a date.
WEEKDAY.ad: is a number that represents a date!is a number: for Sunday=1 through Saturday=7, use 1; for Monday=1 through Sunday=7, use 2; for Monday=0 through Sunday=6, use 3

WEEKNUM.d: Returns the week number in the year
WEEKNUM.ad: is the date-time code used by Spreadsheet Editor for date and time calculation!is a number (1 or 2) that determines the type of the return value

WORKDAY.d: Returns the serial number of the date before or after a specified number of workdays
WORKDAY.ad: is a serial date number that represents the start date!is the number of nonweekend and non-holiday days before or after start_date!is an optional array of one or more serial date numbers to exclude from the working calendar, such as state and federal holidays and floating holidays

WORKDAY.INTL.d: Returns the serial number of the date before or after a specified number of workdays with custom weekend parameters
WORKDAY.INTL.ad: is a serial date number that represents the start date!is the number of nonweekend and non-holiday days before or after start_date!is a number or string specifying when weekends occur!is an optional array of one or more serial date numbers to exclude from the working calendar, such as state and federal holidays and floating holidays

YEAR.d: Returns the year of a date, an integer in the range 1900-9999.
YEAR.ad: is a number in the date-time code used by Spreadsheet Editor

YEARFRAC.d: Returns the year fraction representing the number of whole days between start_date and end_date
YEARFRAC.ad: is a serial date number that represents the start date!is a serial date number that represents the end date!is the type of day count basis to use

BESSELK.ad: is the value at which to evaluate the function!is the order of the function

CHAR.d: Returns the character specified by the code number from the character set for your computer
CHAR.ad: is a number between 1 and 255 specifying which character you want

CLEAN.d: Removes all nonprintable characters from text

CODE.d: Returns a numeric code for the first character in a text string, in the character set used by your computer

CONCATENATE.d: Joins several text strings into one text string

CONCAT.d: Concatenates a list or range of text strings

DOLLAR.d: Converts a number to text, using currency format
DOLLAR.ad: is a number, a reference to a cell containing a number, or a formula that evaluates to a number!is the number of digits to the right of the decimal point. The number is rounded as necessary; if omitted, Decimals = 2

EXACT.d: Checks whether two text strings are exactly the same, and returns TRUE or FALSE. EXACT is case-sensitive
EXACT.ad: is the first text string!is the second text string

FIND.d: Returns the starting position of one text string within another text string. FIND is case-sensitive
FIND.ad: is the text you want to find. Use double quotes (empty text) to match the first character in Within_text; wildcard characters not allowed!is the text containing the text you want to find!specifies the character at which to start the search. The first character in Within_text is character number 1. If omitted, Start_num = 1

FINDB.d: Finds the specified substring (string-1) within a string (string-2) and is intended for languages the double-byte character set (DBCS) like Japanese, Chinese, Korean etc.
FINDB.ad: is the text you want to find. Use double quotes (empty text) to match the first character in string-2; wildcard characters not allowed!is the text containing the text you want to find!specifies the character at which to start the search. The first character in string-2 is character number 1. If omitted, start-pos = 1

FIXED.d: Rounds a number to the specified number of decimals and returns the result as text with or without commas

MIDB.d: Extracts the characters from the specified string starting from any position and is intended for languages that use the double-byte character set (DBCS) like Japanese, Chinese, Korean etc.

RIGHT.d: Returns the specified number of characters from the end of a text string

EXPAND.ad: The array to expand.!The number of rows in the expanded array. If missing, rows will not be expanded.!The number of columns in the expanded array. If missing, columns will not be expanded.!The value with which to pad. The default is #N/A.

XMATCH.d: Returns the relative position of an item in an array. By default, an exact match is required
XMATCH.ad: is the value to search for!is the array or range to search!specify how to match the lookup_value against the values in lookup_array!specify the search mode to use. By default, a first to last search will be used

FILTER.ad: the range or array to filter!an array of booleans where TRUE represents a row or column to retain!returned if no items are retained

ARRAYTOTEXT.d: Returns a text representation of an array
ARRAYTOTEXT.ad: the array to represent as text!the format of the text

SORT.ad: the range or array to sort!a number indicating the row or column to sort by!a number indicating the desired sort order; 1 for ascending order (default), -1 for descending order!a logical value indicating the desired sort direction: FALSE to sort by row (default), TRUE to sort by column

SORTBY.d: Sorts a range or array based on the values in a corresponding range or array
SORTBY.ad: the range or array to sort!the range or array to sort on!a number indicating the desired sort order; 1 for ascending order (default), -1 for descending order

GETPIVOTDATA.d: Extracts data stored in a PivotTable.
GETPIVOTDATA.ad: is the name of the data field to extract data from!is a reference to a cell or range of cells in the PivotTable that contains the data you want to retrieve!field to refer to!field item to refer to

IMPORTRANGE.d: Imports a range of cells from a specified spreadsheet.
IMPORTRANGE.ad: is the URL of the spreadsheet from where data will be imported!is the range to import
